content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Mikayla Chandler: I was born in the Philippines, but I moved to the United States when I was just five years old. My family settled in Seattle, Washington, and I grew up in a small apartment on the outskirts of the city. My parents worked hard to make ends meet—my father was a mechanic, and my mother worked part-time at a local grocery store. We didn't have much, but we always had each other. I remember my childhood as being full of laughter, even though we struggled financially. I was a quiet kid, more interested in books than playing outside, which probably explains why I ended up pursuing education so seriously. I went to a public high school, and though the resources were limited, I was determined to get into a good university. I eventually earned a graduate degree in public policy, which has helped me in my current job as a community outreach coordinator for a nonprofit that supports immigrant families. I met my husband, David, while I was in graduate school—he was a fellow volunteer at the same organization. We got married a few years ago, and we now have a two-year-old daughter, Lily. Life hasn't been easy, but I've always believed in working hard and making the most of the opportunities I've been given.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Mikayla Chandler: Yes, there was a moment that changed everything for me. I was 17, still in high school, and I had just received a scholarship to a community college. It was the first time I felt like I had a real shot at something bigger. But at the same time, my father was laid off from his job, and we were barely getting by. My parents were worried about how we would afford the tuition and the expenses that came with it. I remember sitting at the kitchen table, staring at the scholarship letter, feeling both excited and terrified. I didn't want to leave my family behind, but I also knew that staying in Seattle without any real education would limit my future. I talked it over with my mother, who had always encouraged me to pursue my dreams, even when we didn't have much. She reminded me that I had worked hard in school and that this was an opportunity I couldn't let slip away. That night, I made the decision to take the scholarship and move to a different city for college. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was also the best. That choice led me to meet people who shaped my worldview, to study public policy, and ultimately to the work I do today. Looking back, I realize that moment was the turning point that set me on the path to the life I have now.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Mikayla Chandler: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. I had to weigh so many things—my family's needs, my own dreams, the uncertainty of moving away. But in the end, I realized that I couldn't let fear or hardship dictate my future. I made a plan, talked it through with my mother, and committed to making it work. I didn't just 'fall into' this path; I chose it, even when it felt like a leap of faith. That decision taught me the value of agency and the importance of believing in yourself, even when the world around you feels uncertain.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Mikayla Chandler: Absolutely. I think if I had known about more resources or had someone to talk to about my options, it might have made the decision easier. At the time, I didn't really know where to turn for guidance—my parents were doing their best, but they didn't have the experience to help me navigate the college application process. If there had been a mentor or a community organization that could have offered support, like financial aid counseling or career planning, I think it would have made a huge difference. In fact, that's why I now volunteer with the nonprofit I work for. I want to make sure that other young people, especially those from similar backgrounds, don't have to make that decision alone. It's not just about getting into college—it's about having the tools and support to make the right choice for your future.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Mikayla Chandler: Yes, I have a partner and a daughter. I married David when I was 28, and we met through our volunteer work at the nonprofit where I now work as a community outreach coordinator. David is a teacher at a local middle school, and he's been incredibly supportive of my career and my goals. We have a two-year-old daughter named Lily, who is the light of our lives. She's a curious and energetic child, and I love watching her explore the world with such wonder. Having a family has given me a new perspective on the work I do—especially with immigrant families, many of whom are navigating the same challenges I did. It reminds me every day why it's so important to advocate for accessible education and support systems. My parents are still in Seattle, and though we don't see them as often as we'd like, they're a big part of our lives. My mother, in particular, has been my biggest supporter throughout my life, and I'm grateful for her strength and wisdom.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how far I've come, and how much my past has shaped who I am today. Talking about my childhood, my struggles, and the pivotal decision to leave home for college brought back a lot of emotions—both the fear and the hope I felt at 17. It was also humbling to reflect on how much support I needed back then and how I now strive to give that same support to others through my work. Sharing my story with someone else, especially in such depth, made me realize how important it is to not only remember where I came from but also to use that experience to help others find their way. It's a responsibility I take seriously, and one that fuels my passion for community outreach and advocacy.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Mikayla Chandler: My immediate family includes my younger brother, Jason, who is 22 and works as a freelance graphic designer. We were very close growing up, even though we didn't have much. He always had a creative streak, and I remember how he would draw pictures on the walls of our apartment when he was a kid—something my parents never really stopped us from doing. We haven't always seen eye to eye, especially when he was younger and wanted to take a different path than what I thought was practical, but over time, I've come to admire his independence and passion. He's someone who never lets fear hold him back, and I think that's something I've learned from him as much as he's learned from me. We still keep in touch, and I'm proud of the person he's become. He's also been a big support to me in my work, offering to design materials for the nonprofit I work with. It's nice to have that kind of connection with a sibling, even when our lives have taken different directions.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Mikayla Chandler: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been incredibly important to me. One of them is Sarah, a fellow volunteer at the nonprofit I work for. We met during a community event, and we've been close ever since. She's a social worker with a passion for immigrant rights, and her work has inspired me in so many ways. We often collaborate on projects, and she's been a great sounding board for my ideas. Then there's my mentor, Mr. Thompson, who was the director of the nonprofit when I first started working there. He saw potential in me and took me under his wing, offering guidance and encouragement when I was still finding my footing. His belief in me gave me the confidence to take on more responsibilities and eventually move into my current role. I also have a few close friends from college who I still keep in touch with, even though life has taken us in different directions. They've been there for me through both good times and bad, and I'm grateful for their friendship. These people, along with my family, have helped shape who I am today, and I wouldn't be where I am without them.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Mikayla Chandler: I live in a neighborhood called Capitol Hill in Seattle, which is vibrant, diverse, and full of life. It's a bit of a contrast to where I grew up—back then, we were in a quieter, more working-class area on the outskirts of the city. Capitol Hill is more urban, with a lot of small businesses, coffee shops, and community centers. I love that there's always something going on, whether it's a local art show, a food festival, or a neighborhood meeting. It's a place where people from all walks of life come together, which feels very in line with the work I do. My apartment is in a building with other young professionals and families like mine, and it's nice to feel part of a community that values inclusivity and support. I also appreciate how accessible public services and cultural institutions are here—there are libraries, clinics, and nonprofits that offer resources to people like me who are still navigating the challenges of building a life in this country. Living here reminds me that while my past shaped me, I'm now part of something bigger, and I'm grateful for the opportunities this neighborhood provides.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Mikayla Chandler: I feel pretty safe here, though I know it's not the case for everyone. Capitol Hill has a strong sense of community, and there are always people around who look out for one another. That said, I'm not naïve—I know that safety can be relative, and there are parts of the city where people don't feel as secure. For me, though, the mix of cultures, the presence of local organizations that support vulnerable populations, and the fact that I've built a life here with my family make me feel grounded. I also take precautions, like being aware of my surroundings and trusting my instincts. It's a balance, but overall, I feel safe in my neighborhood, and that gives me peace of mind, especially knowing that my daughter is growing up in a place where she can feel seen and supported.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Mikayla Chandler: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the sense of community and the opportunities that come with being in a place like Capitol Hill. There's always something new to learn or experience, and I feel like I'm part of a bigger movement toward inclusivity and support for people from all backgrounds. That aligns perfectly with the work I do, and it gives me a sense of purpose every day. But it's not without its challenges. The cost of living here is high, and even with my job, it can be stressful trying to balance my income with rent, groceries, and my daughter's needs. I also sometimes feel the weight of being an immigrant in a city that, while welcoming, still has its own set of barriers. There are days when I miss the simplicity of my childhood in Seattle's outskirts, where life was slower and the relationships were more tightly knit. But I remind myself that I'm here for a reason—to build a better future for my daughter and to help others who are still finding their way. It's a constant balancing act, but I wouldn't trade this life for anything.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has evolved since my childhood in Seattle. Talking about my partner, David, and our daughter, Lily, reminded me of how deeply my personal experiences shape the work I do with immigrant families. It also made me appreciate how far I've come—from a quiet kid in a small apartment to someone who now helps others navigate the same challenges I once faced. When I described my neighborhood, Capitol Hill, I felt a mix of pride and gratitude. It's a place that feels alive and full of possibility, but it also comes with its own set of struggles, like the high cost of living. Still, I feel safe and supported here, which is something I never took for granted growing up. It's comforting to know that I'm not just surviving, but thriving, and that I can now be a source of support for others who are still finding their way.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Mikayla Chandler: A typical week for me is pretty varied, but there's a rhythm to it. I start most mornings around 6:30 a.m., getting my daughter Lily ready for preschool while trying to keep up with my own morning routine. I usually have a quick breakfast, then head into the office by 8:00 a.m. My job as a community outreach coordinator keeps me pretty busy—most days involve meetings with local organizations, planning events for immigrant families, or even just one-on-one conversations with people who need help navigating resources. I also make time to check in with my team and review upcoming projects. After work, I pick Lily up and we usually have some time together—whether it's going to the park, cooking dinner, or just reading a book. On weekends, I try to balance family time with some personal time. Sometimes I meet up with friends or attend community events, especially ones that align with my work. Other times, I use the weekend to catch up on errands or just relax. It's not always perfect, but I find comfort in the structure and the small moments that make life meaningful.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Mikayla Chandler: I work as a community outreach coordinator for a nonprofit organization called 'Seattle Bridges,' which focuses on supporting immigrant families with resources like housing assistance, language classes, and access to healthcare. I work full time, typically from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, though my schedule can get a bit flexible depending on events or meetings. My job is demanding but incredibly rewarding—I get to meet people from all over the world, hear their stories, and help them navigate the systems that can feel so overwhelming. I also occasionally work late or on weekends when we're planning big events or workshops, but I try to maintain a balance so I can be there for Lily and my family. It's not always easy, but knowing that my work makes a difference in someone else's life keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Mikayla Chandler: Outside of my job and family time, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to exercise at least a few times a week—whether it's a morning walk with Lily or a yoga session at home. I find that it helps me clear my mind and stay focused, especially with the demands of my work. I also have a small habit of journaling in the evenings, mostly just to reflect on the day and write down any thoughts or ideas that come to me. It's a way to process everything and keep my priorities in check. I also make it a point to learn something new every week, whether it's through online courses, podcasts, or just reading articles about public policy or social justice. It keeps me engaged and reminds me why I chose this path in the first place. And of course, I try to cook meals from different cultures—especially ones that remind me of my heritage. It's a small way to connect with my roots while also sharing that with Lily, so she can learn about where we came from.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Mikayla Chandler: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started doing short meditation sessions with Lily while we have our breakfast, which has been a nice way to start the day with intention. It's something I've been inspired to do after attending a workshop at the nonprofit I work for on mental health and self-care for immigrant communities. I realized how important it is to take care of myself so I can show up fully for my work and my family. It's still a work in progress, but I've noticed a difference in how I handle stress and stay present throughout the day. I also began setting aside time each evening to call my parents, which has been a meaningful way to stay connected despite the distance. It's funny how small changes can have such a big impact on your overall well-being.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Mikayla Chandler: Lily is two years old now, so her days are still pretty flexible, but we've started establishing some routines as she gets used to preschool. On a typical weekday, she wakes up around 7:00 a.m., and after a quick breakfast, we head to her preschool by 8:30 a.m. The school is right across the street from our apartment, which makes things easier for me. She stays there until 3:00 p.m., and then we pick her up. After that, we usually have a snack, and then I try to make time for some play or reading. She loves playing with her blocks and drawing, and I often take her to the park nearby if the weather is nice. On some days, she participates in small group activities at the preschool, like music or storytelling, which I think helps her social development. I also try to make sure she has a bedtime routine—bath, story, and then lights out by 8:00 p.m. It's a work in progress, but I'm learning as I go. Watching her grow and explore the world reminds me of how important it is to create a safe and nurturing environment for her, especially since I know what it's like to have to navigate life without much support.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life has evolved, especially in terms of my family, my neighborhood, and my daily routines. Talking about my partner, David, and our daughter, Lily, reminded me of how deeply my personal experiences shape the work I do with immigrant families. It also made me appreciate how far I've come—from a quiet kid in a small apartment to someone who now helps others navigate the same challenges I once faced. Describing my neighborhood, Capitol Hill, filled me with a mix of pride and gratitude. It's a place that feels alive and full of possibility, but it also comes with its own set of struggles, like the high cost of living. Still, I feel safe and supported here, which is something I never took for granted growing up. It's comforting to know that I'm not just surviving, but thriving, and that I can now be a source of support for others who are still finding their way. Reflecting on my job and daily routines also reminded me of the balance I strive for—between work, family, and self-care. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to prioritize what matters most and find joy in the small moments that make life meaningful.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Mikayla Chandler: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I've had my share of challenges over the years. Growing up in a low-income household, we didn't always have access to regular healthcare, and that's something I've been more mindful of as an adult. I've made it a priority to see a doctor regularly now, especially since becoming a parent. I have a history of mild anxiety, which I've learned to manage through mindfulness and talking to friends or my therapist when needed. I also used to struggle with insomnia, but the meditation practice I started recently has helped a lot with that. I try to eat healthy, mostly plant-based meals, and I make sure to stay active with walks or yoga. I've also been more aware of the stress that comes with my job, so I've started setting boundaries to make sure I'm not burning out. Overall, I feel like I'm taking better care of myself now, and that's something I want to model for Lily as she grows up.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Mikayla Chandler: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that includes movement, mindfulness, and nourishing food. I've found that even small things, like walking with Lily in the morning or taking a few minutes to breathe before starting my day, help me feel more grounded. But what makes it hard is the constant balancing act between work, family, and self-care. There are days when I get so caught up in meetings or helping Lily with her bedtime routine that I forget to take a break or eat properly. I also struggle with the stress that comes with knowing how much is at stake for my family and the people I work with. It's not always easy to prioritize my own health when there are so many other demands, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and recognize that taking care of my well-being is just as important as everything else.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Mikayla Chandler: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic back pain that I think I developed from years of sitting at a desk and not always taking the time to stretch or move properly. It started becoming more noticeable a year ago, and I finally made an appointment with a physical therapist. They diagnosed me with mild lumbar strain, which they said was likely from poor posture and lack of core strength. It's been a bit of a wake-up call for me to take my physical health more seriously. I've started incorporating more stretching into my daily routine and even joined a local yoga class that's been really helpful. The pain isn't gone, but it's definitely more manageable now. It's funny how something that feels so small—like sitting at a desk for eight hours—can have such a big impact on your body over time. I've also been more mindful of how stress affects my physical health, and I've made it a point to schedule regular check-ups and not ignore my body's signals anymore.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Mikayla Chandler: The back pain hasn't really stopped me from working or caring for Lily, but it has definitely made me more aware of how important it is to take breaks and listen to my body. There were a few days when the pain was worse, and I had to adjust my schedule a bit—like taking shorter walks or sitting with a cushion to relieve the pressure. I also had to be more intentional about not pushing through the pain just to get things done. It's been a lesson in patience, both for myself and for my work. I've learned that I can still be productive without sacrificing my health, and that has actually made me more efficient in the long run. I think the biggest challenge was adjusting my mindset—from seeing my body as something I could push through to seeing it as something I need to take care of. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the reminder that my health is a foundation for everything else in my life, including my ability to support my family and do the work I love.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Mikayla Chandler: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel incredibly grateful for where I am, and other days I feel the weight of everything I'm juggling. Becoming a mother has changed me in ways I never anticipated. There's this constant love and joy that comes with watching Lily grow, but there's also this deep sense of responsibility that can be overwhelming. I've had moments where I feel like I'm not doing enough, like I'm not giving her the perfect life or being the perfect parent. But I've also learned to be more compassionate with myself, to recognize that no one has all the answers, and that showing up every day with love and intention is what matters most. Professionally, I've been proud of the work I've done with our nonprofit, especially during the pandemic when so many immigrant families were struggling. It was challenging, but it also reminded me of why I chose this path. I've felt a sense of purpose, even when I've felt burnt out. Overall, it's been a year of growth, both personally and professionally, and I'm trying to embrace the journey, even when it's messy.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and well-being have become a priority in my life, especially as I balance work, family, and personal growth. Talking about my recent changes to my daily routine, like incorporating mindfulness and staying connected with my parents, reminded me of how small, intentional actions can have a big impact on my overall sense of peace and clarity. It also made me think about how my past experiences with limited access to healthcare shaped my current mindset—now, I'm more proactive about taking care of myself, not just for my own sake, but also to be the best version of myself for Lily and the people I work with. Reflecting on my health challenges, like the chronic back pain, reminded me of how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signals it sends. It's a reminder that I'm not just surviving, but learning to thrive, and that taking care of my health is just as important as the work I do in the community.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Mikayla Chandler: I've definitely struggled with anxiety at times, especially when I was younger and felt like I was constantly trying to prove myself—whether it was in school, in my career, or even in my personal life. There were moments when I felt like I wasn't enough, like I had to work twice as hard to be seen or accepted. Now, as a mother and a professional, that anxiety still shows up, but in different ways. It's not about proving myself anymore—it's about making sure I'm doing the best I can for Lily and the people I work with. I've learned to recognize when that anxiety is creeping in, and I try to address it through mindfulness, talking to friends, or even just taking a few deep breaths when things feel overwhelming. I also see a therapist occasionally, which has been really helpful in navigating these feelings. I don't think I'm alone in this—so many people, especially women and immigrants, carry a lot of invisible weight. But I've come to understand that it's okay to not be okay, and that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Mikayla Chandler: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and growth. David has been incredibly supportive, but he's also been dealing with his own stress—his job as a teacher has been demanding, especially with the changes in education policies and the ongoing challenges of remote learning. He's had to put in extra hours, and I can see how it's taken a toll on him. But he's also been a rock for me, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed with work or parenting. As for Lily, she's been a constant source of joy, but also a reminder of how much responsibility comes with being a parent. We've had our ups and downs, like any new parents, but I think we're learning to navigate it together. My parents, though they're not as close as I'd like, have been trying to stay involved in Lily's life, and that means a lot to me. It's not perfect, but I feel like we're all growing through this, even when it's hard.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Mikayla Chandler: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't been a central part of my life, though I respect the role it plays for many people. Growing up, my family wasn't particularly religious, and I never felt the need to define my identity through a specific faith. That said, I do believe in something bigger than myself—whether it's the resilience of the human spirit, the power of community, or the idea that we all have a role to play in making the world a better place. I think of my work with immigrant families as a kind of spiritual practice, one that's rooted in compassion, empathy, and service. It's not about believing in a higher power, but about believing in the connections we build with one another and the impact we can have on each other's lives. I also find meaning in small, everyday moments—like watching Lily laugh, or seeing someone I've helped find their way in this country. In that sense, I think I have my own kind of spirituality, one that's shaped by experience, love, and the belief that we're all in this together.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Mikayla Chandler: I use social media mostly as a tool to stay connected with my community and share resources. I'm on Facebook quite a bit, especially the local groups in Capitol Hill and ones focused on immigrant support. I find that these groups are full of people who are going through similar experiences, and it's comforting to know I'm not alone. I also follow a few advocacy pages that highlight issues affecting immigrant families, which helps keep me informed and inspired in my work. Instagram, on the other hand, is more for personal connections—I follow a few local artists and activists who share messages of hope and resilience. I don't use it as much for work, but I do post occasionally about our nonprofit's events or success stories. It's a way to show the community what we're doing and encourage others to get involved. I've also started using LinkedIn more recently to network with professionals in my field and stay updated on policy changes that might affect the people I work with. Overall, I see social media as a double-edged sword—it can be overwhelming with all the noise, but when used intentionally, it can be a powerful tool for connection and change.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Mikayla Chandler: I think social media has been a mixed experience for me during tough times. On one hand, I've found emotional support in online communities, especially those focused on immigrant experiences or parenting. There are times when I feel overwhelmed with work or parenting challenges, and seeing others share similar struggles helps me feel less alone. I've even reached out to people in those groups for advice or just to vent, and they've been really supportive. Financial support, though, hasn't been something I've relied on through social media. I've always believed in being self-sufficient and making my own way, even when it's hard. That said, I have used Facebook to share our nonprofit's fundraising campaigns, and it's been amazing to see how the community comes together to support causes they care about. It's a reminder that even in difficult times, people are willing to help when they see a need—and that gives me hope.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on my health and emotional well-being, especially as I navigate the challenges of work, family, and personal growth. Talking about my chronic back pain reminded me of how something as simple as sitting at a desk for long hours can have lasting effects on the body, and how important it is to take proactive steps to care for myself. It also made me realize how much my past experiences with limited access to healthcare have shaped my current mindset—now, I'm more proactive about seeking help and not ignoring my body's signals. Reflecting on my struggles with anxiety, especially as a mother and professional, reminded me of how deeply I carry the weight of responsibility, but also how far I've come in learning to be compassionate with myself. I've come to understand that it's okay not to be okay, and that seeking support is a sign of strength, not weakness. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in these feelings, and that my community, both online and offline, is a source of strength and connection during difficult times.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Mikayla Chandler: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels fluctuate more than before, especially with the added pressures of being a working parent and managing my back pain. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling too many things at once, and I worry I'm not doing enough for Lily or for the families I work with. But I've also been working on my emotional coping strategies. I've started setting aside specific times to check in with myself—whether it's a short meditation, a walk in the park, or just sitting with my thoughts without judgment. I've also been more open with David about my feelings, which has helped me feel less isolated. I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from my partner, my therapist, or even my friends. I'm still figuring out what works best for me, but I'm trying to be more intentional about taking care of my emotional well-being. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that self-compassion is just as important as pushing forward.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Mikayla Chandler: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and Lily's daycare. Rent alone takes up about a third of my income, which is tough because Capitol Hill is so expensive. I've been trying to be careful with our budget, but it's still a constant balancing act. Groceries are another big one—especially since I try to buy organic and healthy foods for Lily, which can be pricey. Daycare is also a significant cost, and I've had to look into subsidies or sliding scale options to make it work. I also set aside money for my car payments, insurance, and occasional expenses like co-pays for my physical therapy sessions. It's not always easy to track everything, but I've started using a budgeting app to keep things organized. It's frustrating sometimes, knowing that even with a full-time job, we're still stretching every dollar. But I remind myself that we're doing okay, and that we're building a life that's stable and full of love for Lily.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Mikayla Chandler: Last month, our household spent around $3,200, which is actually a bit lower than our usual monthly spending. Normally, we budget around $3,500 to $3,700, depending on the month. The biggest chunk of that goes to rent, which is about $1,600, and daycare, which is roughly $1,200. Groceries usually come in at around $600, and I also set aside about $300 for transportation and insurance. I've been trying to cut back on non-essential expenses, like eating out or buying new clothes, to make ends meet. Sometimes, I feel like we're always just one unexpected expense away from being behind, but I've learned to be really careful with our money. I also use a budgeting app to track everything, and it helps me see where we can make small adjustments. It's not always easy, but I remind myself that we're building a stable life for Lily, and that gives me the motivation to keep going.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Mikayla Chandler: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in Capitol Hill, and while it's not huge, it feels cozy and functional for our family. Renting has been the practical choice for us, especially with the way the housing market is here. I've considered buying someday, but with the high costs and the uncertainty of how long we'll stay in one place, it just doesn't feel like the right move right now. Our landlord is pretty understanding, and the building has good amenities like a community garden and a shared laundry room, which I appreciate. It's not perfect, but it's a place that feels like home for Lily and me, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Mikayla Chandler: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and Lily's needs. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up quite a bit, and we had to adjust our budget to cover that. We also had to pay for some unexpected repairs in the apartment, like a leaky pipe that needed fixing. Then there were the holidays—Christmas and Hanukkah, even though we don't celebrate the latter, we still wanted to make it special for Lily. We ended up spending a bit more on gifts and decorations, which wasn't in our original budget. On the flip side, when school started back up in the fall, we had to pay for some new supplies and clothes for Lily, which added to our expenses. But when school ended, we had a bit more flexibility with our budget. I've also noticed that our grocery bills tend to be higher in the summer when we buy more fresh produce and try to eat out less. It's been a learning experience, really, to stay flexible and not get too rigid with our finances. I've started setting aside a small emergency fund now, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not much, but it gives me peace of mind knowing we're a little more prepared for the ups and downs of the year.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and I are connected, both emotionally and practically. Talking about my family's experiences—David's challenges as a teacher, Lily's growth as a parent, and my parents' efforts to stay involved—reminded me of how much we all rely on each other for support. It also made me think about how my past struggles with limited access to healthcare have shaped my current mindset around taking care of my body and seeking help when needed. Reflecting on my use of social media, especially Facebook and Instagram, reminded me of how these platforms can be both a source of connection and a place of overwhelm. I've come to see them as tools that, when used intentionally, can help me stay informed, find community, and even support causes I care about. It's comforting to know that even in difficult times, I'm not alone, and that the people around me—both online and offline—are part of the support system that helps me keep going.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Mikayla Chandler: I do have a savings account, though it's not as substantial as I'd like it to be. I started setting money aside a few years ago, mostly as a way to prepare for unexpected expenses—like Lily's daycare costs or medical bills. I try to contribute a little each month, even if it's just $50 or $100, depending on how our budget is looking. It's not a lot, but it gives me a sense of security, especially knowing how unpredictable life can be. I also have a small emergency fund tucked away in a separate account, which I only use for real emergencies. I know I could be saving more, but I also want to make sure we have enough to cover our basic needs and give Lily the best start in life. It's a balance I'm still learning to navigate, but I'm proud of the progress we've made so far.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Mikayla Chandler: In the last year, I've been saving more with the intention of building a rainy day fund, especially since I've been dealing with my back pain and the ongoing costs of being a working parent. I know that unexpected expenses can come up at any time, and I want to make sure we're prepared for things like emergency medical visits, car repairs, or even a sudden increase in daycare costs. I haven't been saving for a home yet, mostly because I'm not sure if we'll stay in Seattle long-term or if buying a house is even feasible right now. But I do feel more confident about my savings than I did a few years ago. It's still a small amount, but it's something I can build on over time. I also try to be intentional about how I spend money—prioritizing what's truly necessary and cutting back on things that aren't. It's not always easy, but I believe that even small steps toward financial security can make a big difference in the long run.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Mikayla Chandler: In my current occupation as a community outreach coordinator for 'Seattle Bridges,' I focus on connecting immigrant families with essential resources and support systems. My most important activities include organizing workshops on topics like housing rights, healthcare access, and language learning, as well as one-on-one case management to help individuals navigate complex systems like the public school district or social services. I also collaborate with local organizations, attend community meetings, and build relationships with families to understand their unique needs. What I find most rewarding is when someone shares with me how my help has made a difference in their life—whether it's finding stable housing, getting their children enrolled in school, or simply feeling less alone in a new country. It's a lot of work, but knowing that I'm helping others avoid the struggles I once faced makes it all worth it.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Mikayla Chandler: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year or if we're planning a big event. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but there are days when I stay late to wrap up a project or meet with a family who needs extra support. I also spend a good chunk of my time on the phone or traveling to different community centers, schools, or clinics to meet with people in person. It's not always a nine-to-five job, but I've learned to manage my time so I can be there for Lily when it matters most. I try to leave work at a reasonable hour so I can have dinner with my family and not miss out on the little moments that make life worth it.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Mikayla Chandler: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've focused on my role with 'Seattle Bridges' since I started working there full-time after finishing my graduate degree. I did take on some part-time freelance writing gigs a few years ago, mostly to supplement my income while I was still in school and trying to make ends meet. But once I got more stable with my nonprofit job, I decided to focus entirely on that. It's demanding, but it's the work I'm passionate about, and I want to be fully present for Lily and my family. I've learned that trying to juggle too many things at once can lead to burnout, and I've made a conscious choice to prioritize what truly matters to me now.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined in my daily life. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how much I've grown in learning to prioritize self-compassion and seek support when needed. It also made me think about how my past struggles with limited resources have shaped my current mindset around budgeting and saving. Reflecting on my monthly expenses and the challenges of making ends meet in Capitol Hill reminded me of how hard it is to balance work, family, and personal health on a limited income. It's comforting to know that I'm not alone in these struggles, and that I have a support system—both emotional and practical—that helps me keep going. I've come to understand that taking care of my mental and financial health is just as important as the work I do for others, and I'm learning to be more intentional about both.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Mikayla Chandler: In total, our household made around $4,200 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary from the nonprofit, and David's income from his teaching job. It's actually a bit higher than usual because David got a small raise at the start of the year, and I also received a performance bonus for the work we did with the immigrant families during the pandemic. It's nice to have a little extra, but I still have to be careful with how we spend it. I've been trying to use that extra money to build up our emergency fund a bit more, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's reassuring to know that we're not just surviving, but we're actually making some progress financially. It's not a lot, but every little bit helps, especially when you're trying to provide for a family and do work that matters.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Mikayla Chandler: I've been at 'Seattle Bridges' for about five years now, and it's been an incredible journey. When I first started, I was still figuring out my role and how to best support the families we work with. Over time, I've grown into my position and taken on more responsibilities, like leading our outreach initiatives and mentoring new staff members. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is a big one, which I'm really grateful for, especially since I've been dealing with my back pain. We also get paid time off, including vacation days and sick leave, which is something I used a lot when Lily was born and during her first few months. The workplace culture is very supportive, and there's a strong sense of mission that keeps everyone motivated. I think what makes this job special is that we're not just doing work for a paycheck—we're making a real difference in people's lives, and that gives me a deep sense of purpose every day.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Mikayla Chandler: My relationships at work are really positive and supportive. I have a great relationship with my manager, Mr. Thompson, who has been a mentor to me since I started. He's always encouraged me to take on new challenges and has given me the freedom to grow into my role. I feel like he genuinely cares about the people we serve and the impact of our work, which aligns with my own values. As for my coworkers, we have a strong sense of camaraderie. We're all passionate about what we do, and there's a lot of collaboration and mutual support. We often have team meetings where we share updates, challenges, and successes, and it's comforting to know that I'm not alone in the work we do. I've formed close friendships with a few of my colleagues, and we often check in with each other, both professionally and personally. It's rare to find a workplace that feels like a community, but that's exactly what 'Seattle Bridges' is for me. It makes the long hours and the stress of the job more bearable, knowing that I'm surrounded by people who are just as committed to making a difference as I am.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Mikayla Chandler: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's definitely some flexibility depending on the needs of the organization and the families we serve. Most weeks, I follow a standard 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. schedule, but I often stay late if we're wrapping up a project or if someone needs extra support. I also have some flexibility in how I manage my time—like if I need to leave a bit early to pick up Lily from daycare or if I have to attend a community meeting in the evening. That said, there are times when the schedule can feel less predictable, especially when we're planning events or responding to urgent needs in the community. I appreciate the flexibility it gives me to balance work and family, but I also know that it can sometimes make it harder to separate work from personal time. It's a trade-off I'm willing to make, though, because the work we do is so meaningful, and I want to be fully present for both my job and my family.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Mikayla Chandler: Overall, I feel like we're in a stable place financially, but it's definitely a tightrope walk. We're not struggling, but we're not exactly thriving either. I know we're doing better than many families I work with, and that gives me a sense of gratitude. At the same time, I'm always thinking about the future—like how we'll afford college for Lily, or if we'll ever be able to buy a home. It's not that I don't trust my ability to work hard, but sometimes I wonder if we'll ever feel truly secure. Still, I try not to let that worry consume me. I remind myself that we're building something together, and that every small step forward matters. I'm proud of how we've managed to make ends meet, and I know that with the right support and a little more time, we can keep moving in the right direction.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life are intertwined in my daily reality. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the unpredictability of life and how important it is to stay flexible with our budget. It also made me think about how my work as a community outreach coordinator not only helps others but also gives me a sense of purpose that balances out the stress of managing our finances. Reflecting on my savings, even though it's not as much as I'd like, reminded me of how far I've come from my childhood, where saving wasn't really a possibility. It's comforting to know that I'm not just surviving, but I'm learning to plan for the future, even in small ways. I'm proud of the progress we've made, and I'm hopeful that with time, we'll continue to build a more secure and stable life for Lily and me.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Mikayla Chandler: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were quite different. My father worked as a mechanic at a local auto shop, and he was always on his feet, fixing cars and dealing with the physical demands of the job. He didn't have much formal education, but he was incredibly skilled and dedicated. My mother worked part-time at a grocery store, often taking shifts in the evenings or on weekends. She had to balance that with taking care of us, which wasn't easy, especially when we were young. I remember her working long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but she always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. Their work was essential for our survival, and I've always been grateful for their sacrifices. It's also why I feel so strongly about supporting immigrant families—so many of them are in the same position, working hard to give their children a better life, just like my parents did for me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Mikayla Chandler: My father's job as a mechanic was demanding but also very hands-on. He spent most of his days in the garage, fixing cars, replacing parts, and making sure vehicles were running smoothly. His most important duties included diagnosing mechanical issues, performing oil changes, and doing repairs that required both strength and precision. He didn't have a lot of formal training, but he was self-taught in many ways, learning through experience and the guidance of his coworkers. He always had his hands dirty, and I remember coming home from school to find him covered in grease, laughing with my mother as he told stories about the day's work. My mother, on the other hand, worked in the grocery store, mostly in the produce section. Her most important activities involved stocking shelves, helping customers find what they needed, and making sure the store was clean and organized. She worked long hours, often coming home tired, but she always made time to cook dinner and help with homework. I think their work, though not glamorous, was essential for our survival, and it taught me the value of hard work and resilience—something I carry with me every day in my own life.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Mikayla Chandler: My father worked at a small auto repair shop owned by a friend of his, and it was a family-run business in a working-class neighborhood in Seattle. The shop was pretty basic—just a few bays, tools spread out on tables, and a lot of grease and oil. They mostly serviced older cars, which meant my father had to be really skilled at figuring out what was wrong with them, often with limited resources. He didn't make a lot of money, but he was respected in the community for his work. My mother worked at a local grocery store that was part of a larger chain, but the store itself was small and had a tight-knit staff. She was responsible for the produce section, which meant she had to be up early every morning to restock, check for spoiled items, and make sure everything was fresh for the customers. She didn't make a lot either, but she always found ways to stretch our food budget and make sure we had enough to eat. Looking back, I realize how much they gave up to provide for us, and it's one of the reasons I'm so passionate about helping immigrant families who are in similar situations. It's a cycle I want to break for others, just as they broke it for me.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Mikayla Chandler: A few years from now, I hope to still be doing the work I love with 'Seattle Bridges,' but I also hope to have more stability—maybe even a small savings account that feels secure, or the ability to take a short trip with my family without worrying about the budget. I hope Lily is growing into a curious, compassionate, and resilient person, someone who knows her worth and isn't afraid to dream big. I also hope to see more progress in the systems that support immigrant families, so that others don't have to face the same struggles I did. I want to be a role model for her, showing her that even when life feels overwhelming, you can still find ways to rise, to help others, and to keep going. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to keep growing, keep learning, and keep fighting for a better world—not just for myself, but for everyone who's still finding their way.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Mikayla Chandler: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with my family, my community, or the people I work with. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of everyday life, but I've learned that the moments that matter most are the ones where I feel seen, supported, and loved. I value the relationships I've built with my parents, my brother, David, and Lily—they're the foundation of who I am. I also value the work I do because it allows me to give back in a way that feels meaningful. There's something deeply fulfilling about helping someone find their way, just as I once did. And I value resilience—the ability to keep going, even when things feel heavy. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've come to see challenges as part of the journey, not as roadblocks. What I value most is the belief that we can all rise, together.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial situation and work life are deeply connected. Talking about our household income and how we manage our budget reminded me of how far I've come from my childhood, where financial stability was a distant dream. It also made me think about the importance of having a job that not only pays the bills but also gives me a sense of purpose. Reflecting on my workplace, 'Seattle Bridges,' and the support I receive there—like health benefits and paid time off—reminded me of how lucky I am to have a job that values its employees and allows me to make a difference in people's lives. It's comforting to know that I'm not just surviving, but I'm building a life that's stable and meaningful, and that gives me hope for the future.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been both a journey of reflection and a reminder of how far I've come. It brought back so many memories—my childhood in Seattle, the difficult decision to leave home for college, the struggles of making ends meet, and the joy of building a life with my family. It also made me realize how much my past has shaped who I am today, and how grateful I am for the people who have supported me along the way. Sharing my story in such depth has reminded me of the importance of resilience, community, and the belief that no matter how hard life gets, there's always a way forward. I'm proud of the person I've become, and I hope that by sharing my experiences, I can inspire others to keep going, even when the path isn't easy.
